Question: How do total penalty yards per game for college football teams correlate with their likelihood of winning, and how do factors like turnovers, opponent strength, or home/away status affect this relationship?
Does the data alreadt exist? Can you get it? Yes, game by game college football data is avaliable from NCAA Stats, ESPN, and Sports Reference, including penalty yars, points scored, turnovers, and game outcomes
Do you need assistance getting it? Potentially if using tables is needed. Otherwise, CSV downloads are avaliable
Time frame needed: The last five seasons (2019-2025) to capture recent trends
Will you need to improve or augment the data? Yes, I may need to combine multiple sources, and use that to identify penalties, points, and turnovers in columns.
Other examples: Sports blogs examine penalties, turnovers, and win probability like Football Outsiders, The Last Man Analytics and The Extra Point.


Code
Football_data |> 
  group_by(Opponent) |> 
summarise(Game = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(Game))


# A tibble: 388 × 2
   Opponent             Game
   <chr>               <int>
 1 Texas                 165
 2 Notre Dame            164
 3 Ohio State            164
 4 Southern California   164
 5 Michigan              163
 6 Oklahoma              162
 7 Alabama               161
 8 Boise State           161
 9 UCLA                  161
10 Clemson               160
# ℹ 378 more rows




Code

  group_by(Outcome) |> 
  summarise(Game = n())


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  Outcome  Game
  <chr>   <int>
1 L       10382
2 W       11628




Code
Football_data |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = Outcome, fill = Outcome)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Game Outcomes",
       x = "Outcome",
       y = "Number of Games") +
  theme_minimal()









A challenge I encountered is that the dataset doesn’t include consistent formatting and is missing thr values for team names and other stats. Additionally, because the data is only data from games, I may need to merge it with another data set to answer a broader question.

title: Big Ten CFB Avg Plays
text:
Big Ten Teams Are Running Fewer Plays After NCAA Clock Change


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(scales)



Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor


Code
CFB24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
CFB25 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
big_ten <- c("Illinois
", "Indiana", "Iowa", "Maryland", "Michigan", "Michigan State
", "Minnesota
", "Nebraska", "Northwestern", "Ohio State", "Penn State", "Purdue", "Rutgers", "Wisconsin")

bigten24 <- CFB24 |> 
  filter(Opponent%in%big_ten)

bigten25 <- CFB25 |> 
  filter(Opponent%in%big_ten)




Code
avg_plays_24 <- bigten24 |> 
  group_by(Opponent) |> 
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))

avg_plays_25 <- bigten25 |> 
  group_by(Opponent) |> 
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_24, 
    aes(
      x = reorder(Opponent, -avg_plays),
      weight = avg_plays
    )) +
      scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Offensive Plays by Opponent (2024 Season)",
    x = "Opponent",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()












Code
library(scales)




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_24, 
    aes(
      x = reorder(Opponent, -avg_plays),
      weight = avg_plays
    )) +
      scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Offensive Plays by Opponent (2024 Season)",
    x = "Opponent",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()













Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_25 , 
    aes(
      x = reorder(Opponent, -avg_plays),
      weight = avg_plays
    )) +
      scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Offensive Plays by Opponent (2025 Season)",
    x = "Opponent",
    y = "Average Offensive Plays"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()









The data shows that most Big Ten teams are running fewer offensive plays per game in 2025 rather than in 2024, supporting the idea that the NCAA’s new timing rule that keeps the clock running after first downs, has shortened possessions. Maryland was the only team that saw a significant increase, most likely reflecting their upbeat offensive style. Overall, the rule change seems to have slightly reduced the pace of plays across the conference.

  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(
    title = "Runs on 3rd and 6 by Top Teams (2021–2025)",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Number of Runs",
    fill = "Year"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_flip()









Reading the Graph: Teams like Florida State, Ole Miss, Michigan, UNLV, New Mexico, Baylor, West Virginia, Air Force, Navy, and Army are listed on the y axis. The x axis represents the number of runs on 3rd and 6 plays, and each color represents a year. Army has shown to have the highest number of runs in 2021, with over 15 runs. Baylor has also had a standout year in 2021 with 13-14 runs. Navy (2022) and Air Force (2023) show high counts around 13. Most teams fluctuate totals from year to year, reflecting new play calling trends. Lastly, Florida State, Ole Miss, and Michigan have lower totals compared to other schools. Across 2021-2025, there were over 16,000 3rd and 6 plays in college football. The most common play types were passes, runs, and few punts along woth other calls like field goals and sacks.
Teams ran the ball over 3,000 times on 3rd and 6, making up about 25% of plays. The average yards gained on these runs was just 2.8, failing to convert. This would suggest that teams use runs to set up a succesful 4th down.
Running on 3rd and 6 isn’t ideal. But some teams take advantage of it more than others. From the data, the top runners include service academies like Army (16 in 2021), Air Force (12 in 2023), and Navy (16 in 2022), along with teams like Baylor (16 in 2021), and UNLV (9 in 2022 and 2024). These teams ran the ball frequenty and this could be because of other options or heavy running plays.
Runs peaked in 2024 with 829 run plays and dropped in 2025 with 487 total running plays, possibly due to changing strategies or rules.
Army leads the group with 44 total runs accross the seasons, followed by Navy and Airforce. Powerhouse offenses with strong rushing players tend to run more, while pass heavy teams like Cleamson run less frequently.
Maryland has had 75 total 3rd and 6 plays from 2021-2025. They ran 15 17 times and gained 2.5 yards. Maryland had 4 run plays in 2021, 6 in 2022, 4 in 2023, 2 in 2024, and 1 in 2025. They have shown a clear downward trend since 2021, with fewer runs in recent years. Maryland’s game has changed and they have become more conservative, more likely passing or punting more to avoid the risk of a loss like the Washington game.
Overall, running on 3rd and 6 is a risky, low reward play that can pay off or also lead to worse. Teams like Army, Navy, and Air Force run it most, while Maryland has dialed it back since 2021.

section: Close Rushing Wins: How Rare Are They?
text:
Close Rushing Wins: How Rare Are They?
It is normally rare for football teams to win without running the ball effectively, but through data it isnt impossible.
Since the 2015 season, fewer than 60% of college football victories have come when the winning team rushed for under 100 yards.

Code
season_games <- logs |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(all_games = n())


season_games_under_100_wins <- logs |> 
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100) |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(low_rush_wins = n())

low_rush_wins <- season_games |> 
  inner_join(season_games_under_100_wins, join_by(Season)) |> 
  mutate(pct_low_rush_wins = low_rush_wins/all_games * 100)

bigten_logs <- logs |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")

bigten_season_games <- bigten_logs |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(all_games = n())


bigten_low_rush_wins <- bigten_logs |> 
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100) |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(low_rush_wins = n())

bigten_combined <- left_join(bigten_season_games, bigten_low_rush_wins, by = "Season") |> 
  mutate(percentage = (low_rush_wins / all_games) * 100)

bigten_combined |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = Season, y = percentage)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line(data = bigten_combined, aes(x = Season, y = percentage), linewidth = 1) +
  geom_point(data = bigten_combined, aes(x = Season, y = percentage)) +
  labs(title = "Rare Rushing Wins: Under 100 Yards to Victory",
       x = "Season",
       y = "Percentage of Wins",
       color = "Group") +
  theme_minimal()









The chart above shows that low-rushing wins make up only a small percentage of all games, with Big Ten teams pulling them off less. The Big Ten is known for its physical, run-heavy style, so when a team wins with fewer than 100 rushing yards, they are going to stand out.
These wins show how the game is evolving toward more pass-first offenses and faster scoring drives, especially in programs willing to lean on their quarterbacks and receivers when the ground game stalls.

title: Penalty Yards and Wins: Does Discipline and Mistakes Decide Game Outcomes?
text:
In college football, where games are decided by small margins, penalties can be the difference between a victory and defeat. A costly false start or holding call might stall a drive, while turnovers or opponent strength can further those effects. My analysis explores how total penalty yards per game correlate with a team’s likelihood of a team winning, and how factors like turnovers, opponent strength, or home/away status influence this relationship. Why should readers care? Penalties aren’t just stats—they’re strategic pitfalls that can cost championships. Understanding them helps coaches, fans, and analysts pinpoint why teams win or lose, especially in an era of increased scrutiny on officiating.
At first I thought I’d merge attendance data to explore how crowd size influences penalties, but quickly realized the attendance dataset lacked direct ties to penalty stats or game outcomes, so I abandoned that to focus on the core football logs. Similarly, I began scraping multiple stats (e.g., interceptions, yards per point) but dropped incomplete blocks when they didn’t add value, pivoting to key metrics like penalty first downs and turnover margin.

title: Penalty Yards and Wins: Does Discipline and Mistakes Decide Game Outcomes?
text:
Data and Methodology
To answer this, I used game-by-game college football data from 2011-2024 data from teamrankings.com for penalty yards, penalty first downs, and turnover margin per game. This provided a richer dataset for correlations. I focused on the last five seasons (2019-2024) to capture recent trends, because older data might not reflect present rules or strategies.

I added, cleaned, and reshaped the TeamRankings data to make tables that would be usable in R.


Code
url <- "https://www.teamrankings.com/college-football/stat/penalty-yards-per-game"

webpage <- read_html(url)

all_logs <- bind_rows(football_data, fb_24) |> 
  filter(season >= 2019)

webpage <- read_html(url)

  html_element("table") |> 
  html_table() |> 
  clean_names()

  select(team, x2025, last_3, home, away, x2024) |> 
  rename(
    pfd_per_game_2025 = x2025,
    pfd_last_3 = last_3,
    pfd_home = home,
    pfd_away = away,
    pfd_per_game_2024 = x2024
  ) |> 
  mutate(across(c(pfd_per_game_2025, pfd_last_3, pfd_home, pfd_away, pfd_per_game_2024), as.numeric))

url_tm <- "https://www.teamrankings.com/college-football/stat/turnover-margin-per-game"
webpage_tm <- read_html(url_tm)
turnover_margin_data <- webpage_tm |> 
  html_element("table") |> 
  html_table() |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  select(team, x2025) |> 
  rename(turnover_margin_2025 = x2025) |> 
  mutate(turnover_margin_2025 = as.numeric(turnover_margin_2025))


if (exists("penalty_first_downs_clean") && "team" %in% names(penalty_first_downs_clean)) {
  merged_data <- penalty_first_downs_clean |> 
    left_join(turnover_margin_data, by = "team") |>
    left_join(
      all_logs |> 
        group_by(team) |> 
        summarise(win_rate = mean(outcome == "W", na.rm = TRUE)),
      by = "team"
    ) |> 
    drop_na()
} else {
  ncaafb <- data.frame(
    Rank = 1:30,
    Team = c("Penn St", "Texas Tech", "Texas", "Navy", "San Diego St", 
             "Ohio St", "Army", "Michigan", "Old Dominion", "Rice", 
             "Kansas St", "Washington", "Wisconsin", "Virginia", "TCU", 
             "Texas St", "Buffalo", "Oregon", "Kennesaw St", "Missouri",
             "Virginia Tech", "N Illinois", "Florida Intl", "Temple", 
             "Miami", "Mississippi St", "Miami OH", "Liberty", "Toledo", "Oklahoma"),
    Conference = c("Big Ten", "Big 12", "Big 12", "AAC", "Mountain West", 
                   "Big Ten", "AAC", "Mountain West", "Sun Belt", "AAC", 
                   "Big 12", "Pac-12", "Big Ten", "ACC", "Big 12", 
                   "Sun Belt", "MAC", "Pac-12", "Sun Belt", "SEC",
                   "ACC", "MAC", "CUSA", "AAC", 
                   "ACC", "SEC", "MAC", "CUSA", "MAC", "Big 12"),
    pfd_perGame_2025 = c(0.5, 0.5, 0.6, 0.6, 0.6, 0.7, 0.7, 0.7, 0.8, 0.8,
                         0.8, 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2,
                         1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.3, 1.3, 1.3, 1.3, 1.3)
  )
  
  merged_data <- ncaafb |> 
    mutate(team_clean = case_when(
      Team == "Penn St" ~ "Penn State",
      Team == "N Illinois" ~ "Northern Illinois",
      TRUE ~ Team
    )) |> 
    left_join(
      all_logs |> 
        group_by(team) |> 
        summarise(win_rate = mean(outcome == "W", na.rm = TRUE)),
      by = c("team_clean" = "team")
    ) |> 
    drop_na() |> 
    rename(pfd_per_game_2025 = pfd_perGame_2025)  
}

title: Penalty Yards and Wins: Does Discipline and Mistakes Decide Game Outcomes?
section: Key Findings: Penalties, Wins, and Influencing Factors
text:
Key Findings: Penalties, Wins, and Influencing Factors
What did I find? Penalty first downs weakly correlate with winning. Teams with more penalty first downs win more often, but the link is not strong. Factors like turnover margin shows that positive turnover margins influence wins especially for more penalty prone teams.


Code
ncaafb <- data.frame(
  Rank = 1:30,
  Team = c("Penn St", "Texas Tech", "Texas", "Navy", "San Diego St", 
           "Ohio St", "Army", "Michigan", "Old Dominion", "Rice", 
           "Kansas St", "Washington", "Wisconsin", "Virginia", "TCU", 
           "Texas St", "Buffalo", "Oregon", "Kennesaw St", "Missouri",
           "Virginia Tech", "N Illinois", "Florida Intl", "Temple", 
           "Miami", "Mississippi St", "Miami OH", "Liberty", "Toledo", "Oklahoma"),
  Conference = c("Big Ten", "Big 12", "Big 12", "AAC", "Mountain West", 
                 "Big Ten", "AAC", "Mountain West", "Sun Belt", "AAC", 
                 "Big 12", "Pac-12", "Big Ten", "ACC", "Big 12", 
                 "Sun Belt", "MAC", "Pac-12", "Sun Belt", "SEC",
                 "ACC", "MAC", "CUSA", "AAC", 
                 "ACC", "SEC", "MAC", "CUSA", "MAC", "Big 12"),
  pfd_perGame_2025 = c(0.5, 0.5, 0.6, 0.6, 0.6, 0.7, 0.7, 0.7, 0.8, 0.8,
                       0.8, 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2,
                       1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.2, 1.3, 1.3, 1.3, 1.3, 1.3)
)

conference_summary <- ncaafb |> 
  group_by(Conference) |> 
  summarise(avg_pfd = mean(pfd_perGame_2025, na.rm = TRUE))

#| label: fig-conference-bar
#| fig-cap: "Average Penalty First Downs per Game by Conference (2025)"
#| fig-alt: "Bar chart showing average penalty first downs per game across college football conferences, reordered from lowest to highest. MAC leads, with teams like Buffalo (1.3) having a 55% win rate despite high penalties."

conference_summary |> 
  arrange(avg_pfd) |>  
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(Conference, avg_pfd), y = avg_pfd, fill = Conference)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    title = "Penalty First Downs Vary by Conference",
    subtitle = "MAC teams lead; Big Ten teams have fewer",
    x = "Conference",
    y = "Avg Penalty First Downs per Game"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

ncaafb_merged <- ncaafb |> 
  mutate(team_clean = case_when(
    Team == "Penn St" ~ "Penn State",
    Team == "N Illinois" ~ "Northern Illinois",
    TRUE ~ Team
  )) |> 
  left_join(all_logs |> group_by(team) |> summarise(win_rate = mean(outcome == "W", na.rm = TRUE)), 
            by = c("team_clean" = "team")) |> 
  drop_na()

top_penalty_teams <- ncaafb_merged |> 
  arrange(desc(pfd_perGame_2025)) |> 
  head(10)

ggplot(top_penalty_teams, aes(x = pfd_perGame_2025, y = win_rate)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, color = "blue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "black") +  
  labs(
    title = "Penalty First Downs and Wins: A Weak but Revealing Link",
    subtitle = "Top 10 teams; based on manual data",
    x = "Avg Penalty First Downs per Game",
    y = "Win Rate"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

This comparison between home and away penalty first downs shows a balanced trend with most points scattered around the diagonal line. However, there is no major skew toward home teams, which suggests that home field advantages dont signifigantly affect how many first downs teams earn from penalties. This variation around the line implies that certain teams or matchups may experience inconsistent officiating, or discipline on the road.

  ggplot(aes(x = Outcome, fill = Outcome)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Game Outcomes",
       x = "Outcome",
       y = "Number of Games") +
  theme_minimal()









A challenge I faced is that the data set doesnt include consistent formatting and is missing the values for team names and other stats. Additionally, because the data is only from games, I will need to marge this with another data set.
##Limitations and Next Steps I initially wanted to measure how penalties directly affect wins, but I found that win totals weren’t clearly included in the data sets I had and the TeamRankings per game tables don’t include outcomes.
In the future, I’d merge this data with a game level data set to calculate correlations between penalty yards and winning percentages

title: Penalty Yards and Wins: Does Discipline and Mistakes Decide Game Outcomes?
text:
Conclusion
The data shows that penalties aren’t consistently related to team success or year to year trends. However, conferences show more distincy behavioral patterns which could be dur to different coaching cultures or officiating tendencies. This matters because it suggests that discipline metrics dont fully explain why teams win, even though they are very helpful.

title: Winning Without the Run
text:
In college football, ground games are always considered a success. But the past decade shows that teams can still win without it. Since 2015, fewer than 6% of all football games have been won by teams rushing for fewer than 100 yards. Even though they are rare, low rush wins have become more common in recent years.

games_clean <- games |> 
  mutate(
    season = year(ymd(Date)),
    result = ifelse(str_detect(Result, "W"), "W", "L")) |> 
      select(season, Team, Conference, RushYds, result)

games_per_season <- games_clean |> 
  group_by(season) |> 
  summarise(TotalGames = n())
  
low_rush_wins <- games_clean |>
  filter(result == "W", RushYds <100) |> 
  group_by(season) |> 
  summarise(LowRushWins = n())

season_summary <- games_per_season |> 
  left_join(low_rush_wins, by = join_by(season)) |> 
  mutate(
    LowRushWins = replace_na(LowRushWins, 0), PctLowRushWins = 100 * LowRushWins/TotalGames)




Code
ggplot(season_summary, aes(x = season, y = PctLowRushWins)) +
geom_line(color = "#b22222", size = 1.2) +
geom_point(color = "#b22222", size = 2) +
labs(
title = "Winning Without the Run Game (2015–Present)",
subtitle = "Percentage of all FBS games won with fewer than 100 rushing yards",
x = "season",
y = "Percent of Wins"
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14)


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.









The trend peaked in 2021, when over 6% of victories came from teams that struggled on the ground. After reaching the highest number in the last decade, this number has remained steady, maintaining 5 to 6% through 2025.


Code
big_ten_summary <- games_clean |> 
filter(str_detect(Conference, "Big Ten")) |> 
group_by(season) |> 
summarise(TotalGames = n()) |> 
left_join(
games_clean |> 
filter(str_detect(Conference, "Big Ten"), result == "W", RushYds < 100) |> 
group_by(season) |> 
summarise(LowRushWins = n()),
by = join_by(season)
) |> 
mutate(
LowRushWins = replace_na(LowRushWins, 0),
PctLowRushWins = 100 * LowRushWins / TotalGames
)

ggplot() +
geom_line(data = season_summary,
aes(x = season, y = PctLowRushWins, color = "All Teams"), size = 1) +
geom_line(data = big_ten_summary,
aes(x = season, y = PctLowRushWins, color = "Big Ten Teams"), size = 1) +
labs(
title = "Low-Rushing Wins: Big Ten vs. National Trends",
x = "season",
y = "Percent of Wins",
color = "Category"
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14)









When focusing on the Big Ten, the numbers show a different story. The Big Ten is known for their physical, run heavy offenses, the conference has still seen its fair share of low rushing wins. In 2021, Big Ten teams won almost 10.5% of their games while rushing for fewer than 100 yards.
Since then, the Big Ten’s percentage has declined but still continues to sit above the overall average, showing that even in a run dominant league, teams are finding ways to win through the air.

title: Winning Without the Run
text:
How the Numbers Were Calculated
Data was collected from football game logs between 2015 and 2025, filtering for games where the winning team recorded fewer than 100 rushing yards. Each season’s total number of games and wins were numbered to determine the percentage of low rushing wins. The same process was repeated for the Big Ten teams to compare conference and national trends.

title: Maryland’s Yards Per Play Trends Reveal a Decade of Middle Ground Football
text:
For the past decade, Maryland football has found itself hovering near the middle of groups. Using yards per play (YPP) data from 2015 through 2025, we can see how the Terrapins balance between offensive and defensive efficiency has shifted season to season, yet remained close to the average.
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(ggrepel)

logs <- read.csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs1525.csv")

winlosslogs <- logs |> 
  mutate(
    wins = case_when(
      grepl("W", Outcome) ~ 1, 
      grepl("L", Outcome) ~ 0
    )
  )

ypp <- winlosslogs |> 
  group_by(TeamFull, Season) |> 
  summarise(
    TotalPlays = sum(TotalPlays),
    TotalYards = sum(TotalYds),
    DefPlays = sum(DefTotalPlays),
    DefYards = sum(DefTotalYds),
    TotalWins = sum(wins)
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards / TotalPlays,
    DefensiveYPP = DefYards / DefPlays
  )


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'TeamFull'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Code
maryland <- winlosslogs |> 
  filter(TeamFull == "Maryland Terrapins")

maryland_ypp <- logs |> 
  filter(TeamFull == "Maryland Terrapins") |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(
    TotalPlays = sum(TotalPlays),
    TotalYards = sum(TotalYds),
    DefPlays = sum(DefTotalPlays),
    DefYards = sum(DefTotalYds),
    TotalWins = sum(Outcome == "W")
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards / TotalPlays,
    DefensiveYPP = DefYards / DefPlays
  )

averages <- winlosslogs |> 
  group_by(TeamFull, Season) |> 
  summarise(
    TotalPlays = sum(TotalPlays),
    TotalYards = sum(TotalYds),
    DefPlays = sum(DefTotalPlays),
    DefYards = sum(DefTotalYds),
    TotalWins = sum(Outcome == "W")
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards / TotalPlays,
    DefensiveYPP = DefYards / DefPlays
  ) |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  summarise(
    offensive_avg = mean(OffensiveYPP), defensive_avg = mean(DefensiveYPP)
  )


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'TeamFull'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Code
off_avg <- averages$offensive_avg
def_avg <- averages$defensive_avg
Each dot on the chart below represents a Maryland season, with its offensive YPP on the x axis and defensive YPP on the y axis. Larger circles indicate more wins, and the black lines mark the averages accross teams and seasons. (5.76 offensive YPP and 5.63 offensive YPP).
Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland_ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.76) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.63) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=maryland_ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, label=Season)
  )+
  labs(title="A Step Back for Maryland", subtitle="The Terps offense and defense puts it among the worst teams in the conference.", caption="Source: NCAA | By Derek Willis")  + theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )

title: Maryland’s Yards Per Play Trends Reveal a Decade of Middle Ground Football
text:
A Decade in the Middle
2015-2017: The Terps’ struggled to find rhythm on either side of the ball, sitting below average offensively and defensively, translating to just three or four wins a year despite 6 in 2016. 2018-2021: Maryland’s offense improved, especially in 2018 (6.13 YPP) and 2021 (6.24 YPP), bringing them closer to competitive territory. However, defensive problems with opponents averaging over 5.7 yards oer play kept the team near the middle. 2022-2023: these are arguable Maryland;s most balanced seasons, with defensive YPP dipping under 5.0 and the team earning eight wins each year, marking a rare pairing of efficiency and results. 2024-2025: A regression followed with offensive production dipping below average. Although the defense steadied in 2025, the year’s data is incomplete.
##What it All Means Maryland’s placement on the grid underscores the pattern of efficiency around the national average. This has made the Terps good enough for bowl eligibility but rarely making in impact within Big Ten teams. If Maryland can pair its occasional offensive bursts with the defensive discipline of 2022-2023, the next data point might finally land above the lines and into competitive story

title: Redzone Efficiency in the NFL: Which Teams Are Improving or Declining?
text:
Redzone performance often determines how successful an NFL offense can be. Teams that convert redzone appearances into touchdowns maximize scoring opportunities , while those that stall leave points on the field. Inspired by an ESPN analysis of redzone success, this code will use expected points added (EPA) to measure how effectively teams perform inside the 20 yard line.
We’ll focus on the 2022 NFL season, comparing each team’s redzone EPA through the first three weeks and through the first nine weeks to see which offenses improved, and which regressed as the season progressed.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(nflreadr)

pbp_2022 <- nflreadr::load_pbp(2022)


According to ESPN’s story, Miami had 20 redzone plays during the first three weeks of the 2022 season with a total EPA of 9.0


Code
miami_redzone_week3 <- pbp_2022 |>
filter(posteam == "MIA",
play_type %in% c("run", "pass"),
yardline_100 <= 20,
week <= 3) |>
summarise(
total_plays = n(),
total_epa = sum(epa)
)
print(miami_redzone_week3)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  total_plays total_epa
        <int>     <dbl>
1          20      9.00




Code
miami_redzone_week9 <- pbp_2022 |> 
  filter(posteam == "MIA", play_type %in% c('run', 'pass'), yardline_100 < 21, week < 4) |> group_by(posteam) |> summarise(plays_week9 = n())


Now, we’ll look at how the Dolphins’ redzone efficiency changed over the 2022 season.


Code
miami_redzone_full <- pbp_2022 %>%
  filter(posteam == "MIA", yardline_100 <= 20, !is.na(epa)) %>%
  summarise(plays = n(), total_epa = sum(epa))
print(miami_redzone_full)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  plays total_epa
  <int>     <dbl>
1   207      7.68


Miami had about 207 redzone plays in 2022 with a total EPA of around 7.68. Compared to 20 in weeks 3 and 9, their ERA per play was strong but dipped later showing inconsistency
Below we are creating data frames for all NFL teams in 2022. One for the first 3 weeks, one for the first 9 weeks, with columns for number of plays and total EPA.


Code
teams_week3 <- pbp_2022 |> 
  filter(week <= 3, yardline_100 <= 20, !is.na(epa)) |> 
  group_by(posteam) |> 
  summarise(plays_week3 = n(), epa_week3 = sum(epa))

teams_week9 <- pbp_2022 |> 
  filter(week <= 9, yardline_100 <= 20, !is.na(epa)) |> 
  group_by(posteam) |> 
  summarise(plays_week9 = n(), epa_week9 = sum(epa))


We’re going to now join both datasets to compare each team’s early and midseason redzone performance


Code
teams_combined <- teams_week3 |> 
  left_join(teams_week9, by = "posteam")

teams_combined <- teams_combined %>%
  dplyr::arrange(desc(epa_week9))


A dumbbell chart makes it easy to visualize how each team’s total EPA inside the redzone changed from week 3 to week 9.


Code
library(ggalt)


Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggalt':
  method                  from   
  grid.draw.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobHeight.absoluteGrob ggplot2
  grobWidth.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobX.absoluteGrob      ggplot2
  grobY.absoluteGrob      ggplot2


Code
teams_combined %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_dumbbell(
    aes(x = epa_week3, xend = epa_week9, y = reorder(posteam, epa_week9)),
    colour = "grey",
    size = 1.5,
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "blue"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "NFL Teams' Redzone EPA: Weeks 1-3 vs. Weeks 1-9 (2022)",
    subtitle = "Green dots represent EPA through week 3; blue dots through week 9. Ordered by highest week 9 EPA.",
    x = "Total EPA",
    y = "Team"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Redzone Efficiency in the NFL: Which Teams Are Improving or Declining?
text:
Findings and Takeaways
This chart compares each NFL team’s redzone EPA added through the first three weeks of the 2022 season (green) to their total EPA through nine weeks (blue). Teams toward the top, such as Kansas City, Philadelphia, and Tennessee, maintained high redzone efficiency throughout the first hald of the season. Their consistent ability to convert scoring opportunities into points helped drive their overall offensive success.
On the other hand, teams like Denver, Buffano, and Tampa Bay had their redzone production stalled, ranking among the lowest in total EPA by week 9. Denver, started poorly and showed no improvement, infact their had declined, reflecting their offensive struggles this year.
A few teams like Baltimore and Cincinnati improved signifigantly between weeks 3 and 9, suggesting that adjustments to play calling or execution began to pay off midseason.
Overall, this analysis shows how early redzone performance can signal offensive rhythm, but it also highlights the teams can build or lose efficiency as defenses adapt and improve over time.

title: Experience Over Everything: Does Seasoned Shooting Set Players Apart?
text: Maryland’s men’s soccer team this season, has been a powerhouse in college soccer, ranking in the nation’s top programs. One key factor they are known for, is the depth of their roster. In this post, we’ll explore how Maryland’s players stack up in terms of scoring efficiency, focusing on goals scored, and compare them to the broader NCAA Division I league. Using data from the 2025 season, we can visualize the distribution of goals by player year across all D-I teams, and focus on Maryland and Virginia to see how experience translates to offensive output.

title: Experience Over Everything: Does Seasoned Shooting Set Players Apart?

title: Experience Over Everything: Does Seasoned Shooting Set Players Apart?
text:
Data and Methodology
I pulled player statistics from the NCAA men’s soccer dataset from the 2025 season. In order to focus in active and impactful platers, I filtered for players with atleast one shot on goal. For the plot, I placed goals schored on the y axis, because it directly measures offensive contribution of goals by player, allowing us to see clustering and outliers.
Maryland’s players in red for emphasis, with Virginia added, who is also a top program, in blue to provide context.


Code
library(tidyverse)

section: Shot Totals Show No Clear Link to Experience
text:
Shot Totals Show No Clear Link to Experience
The graph shows that shots on goal are fairly evently distributed among freshman, sohpmores, juniors, and seniors during the 2025 NCAA Division I Men’s Soccer season. However, there doesn’t appear to be a clear correlation between player year and shot volume.

text:
The Beeswarm Plot: Experience and Goals
This chart shows that goal scoring in NCAA Division I Men’s Soccer is concentrated among a few standout players, regardless of class year. Maryland’s leading scorers, highlighted in red, tend to be upperclassmen, while Virginia’s, shown in blue, are more evently distributed across player years. title: Rushing Trends in the Big Ten. And Where Maryland Falls
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)

Code
library(lubridate)
library(dplyr)

games <- read.csv("~/Downloads/sportsblog/posts/footballlogs25 (1).csv")

bigten <- games |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>
  filter(!is.na(RushYds)) |>
  mutate(Date = ymd(Date)) |>
  mutate(RushingAvg = RushYds / RushAtt)

bigten_avg <- mean(bigten$RushingAvg)
MarylandTerrapins <- bigten |> 
  filter(TeamFull == "Maryland Terrapins")
MarylandTerrapins$RushingAvg <- as.numeric(as.character(MarylandTerrapins$RushYA))
mean(MarylandTerrapins$RushingAvg)


[1] 4.133333


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data = bigten, aes(x = Date, y = RushingAvg, group = TeamFull)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, max(bigten$RushingAvg) * 1.1))









Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = bigten_avg, color = "blue") +  
  geom_line(data = bigten, aes(x = Date, y = RushingAvg, group = TeamFull)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, max(bigten$RushingAvg) * 1.1)) + 
  facet_wrap(~ TeamFull) 









Maryland’s offense has felt stuck for most of the season, and the chart confirms what games have already shown. The Terps struggle to run the ball with consistency. When you compare Maryland’s rushing average against the rest of the Big Ten, the struggle appears clearer.
The overall conference isn’t consistent either. Most Big Ten teams hover around the same areas of four to six yards per carry. Only a few teams break out with anything explosive. But Maryland stands out for the wrong reasons. Their weekly rushing averages are almost always below the conference line. Even when other teams dip, Maryland dips lower. When teams rise, Maryland barelt moves.
Some teams in the Big Ten fluctuate. Michigan has spikes. Oregon explodes in one game. Penn State bounces around. Northwestern and Purdie ride small waves. Everybody moves at least a little. Maryland is different. Their line stays flat, and it stays low, with only one late season jump that looks more like an outlier than a breakthrough.
The story this tells is that Maryland hasn’t been able to create space on the ground, and it shows up week after week. The Terps dont have the line push, breakaway abilitym or the consistency that their conference rivals generate. In a league built on running the football, Maryland is running uphill every time.
The numbers make the problems clear. Maryland’s rushing average barely meets the conference’s. The gap is small, but its steady, and it is enough to slow drives, posessions, and games.

title: Are Maryland’s First Games Reliable Indicators of the Season?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
cbb<- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/dwillis.github.io/main/docs/sports-data-files/cbblogs1526.csv")


Rows: 111554 Columns: 58
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): Season, Opponent, HomeAway, W_L, URL, Conference, Team, OT
dbl  (49): Game, TeamScore, OpponentScore, TeamFG, TeamFGA, TeamFGPCT, Team3...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
maryland <- cbb |> 
  filter(Team == "Maryland")


maryland <- maryland |> 
  mutate(
    Date = ymd(Date),
    TeamScore = TeamScore,
    OpponentScore = OpponentScore,
    PointDiff = TeamScore - OpponentScore
  )

early_season <- maryland |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  filter(Game <= 3)

season_summary <- early_season |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(AvgEarlyDiff = mean(PointDiff))


ggplot(season_summary, aes(x = Season, y = AvgEarlyDiff, group = 1)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Maryland Men's Basketball: Early-Season Point Differential (2015–2025)",
    subtitle = "Maryland's first 3 games of each season",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Avg Point Differential"
  ) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))









Maryland’s early season performances have changed drastically over the last 10 years, but the first three games rarely tell the full story of the season. I looked at the first three games from every season since 2015 and calculated the average point differential for each year. The results show several spikes and drops which makes it hard to identify a consistent pattern.
In some seasons, Maryland started very strong. For example, Maryland averaged ore than 27 points per game in the first three match ups in 2017-2018. The team also opened the 2024-2025 season with its highest early season margin of more than 31 points. But those fast starts did not always predict how the rest of the year went once they reached stronger match up opponents.
Other seasons opened with smaller margins like in 2023-2024, where Maryland averaged only three points per game in its first three match ups. This showed a slow beginning and reflected that early struggled that showed up later in the season as well.
Overall, based on this data, Maryland’s early season games give a preview of how the team looks in November, but they do not consistently predict how the teams will perform later on. This season’s early results fall towards the middle of the long term trend, which suggests that the first three games tell us something, but not enough to make a strong predictive conclusion about the rest of Maryland’s season.

title: What Defines a Buzz Williams Team? A look through Virginia Tech, Texas A&M, and What It Means for Maryland
text:
Buzz Williams has coached 18 seasons as a division I head coach, with recent stops at Virginia Tech (2014-2019) and Texas A&M (2019-2024). Using NCAA game logs from 2015 to present, I analyzed every game he coached in that span to identify what actually defines a Buzz Williams team. Rather than focusing on wins and losses, I wanted to understand the style, statistical identity, and the consistent performance patterns accross different schools and rosters. Then, I compared those traits to Maryland’s performance over the past two seasons to determine how this may shape Maryland’s future.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(lubridate)
library(dplyr)

basketball <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/cbblogs1526.csv")


Rows: 111768 Columns: 59
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Season, TeamFullName, Opponent, HomeAway, W_L, OT, URL, Conferenc...
dbl  (49): Game, TeamScore, OpponentScore, TeamFG, TeamFGA, TeamFGPCT, Team3...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
buzz <- basketball |>
  filter(
    (Team == "Virginia Tech" & Season %in% c("2014-2015","2015-2016","2016-2017","2017-2018","2018-2019")) |
    (Team == "Texas A&M" & Season %in% c("2019-2020","2020-2021","2021-2022","2022-2023","2023-2024","2024-2025"))
  )

buzz_summary <- buzz |> 
  group_by(Team, Season) |> 
  summarise(
  GamesPlayed = n(),
    Wins = sum(W_L == "W"),
    Losses = sum(W_L == "L"),
    AvgPoints = mean(TeamScore),
    AvgOpponentPoints = mean(OpponentScore),
    AvgMargin = mean(TeamScore - OpponentScore),
    FG_PCT = mean(TeamFGPCT),
    ThreeP_PCT = mean(Team3PPCT),
    FT_PCT = mean(TeamFTPCT),
    OffRebounds = mean(TeamOffRebounds),
    TotalRebounds = mean(TeamTotalRebounds),
    Assists = mean(TeamAssists),
    Steals = mean(TeamSteals),
    Blocks = mean(TeamBlocks),
    Turnovers = mean(TeamTurnovers),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )


ggplot(buzz_summary, aes(x=Season, y=AvgMargin, color=Team)) +
  geom_line(size=1.2) +
  geom_point(size=3) +
  labs(
    title = "Buzz Williams Teams: Average Point Margin by Season",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Average Point Margin"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_line()`: Each group consists of only one observation.
ℹ Do you need to adjust the group aesthetic?











Code
bw_efficiency <- buzz |> 
  group_by(Team, Season) |> 
  summarise(
    OffEff = TeamScore / (TeamFG + 0.44 * TeamFTA), 
    DefEff = OpponentScore / (OpponentFG + 0.44 * OpponentFTA),
    TurnoverRate = mean(TeamTurnovers)
  )

dplyr 1.1.0.
ℹ Please use `reframe()` instead.

  always returns an ungrouped data frame and adjust accordingly.


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Team', 'Season'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.


Code
maryland <- basketball |> 
  filter(Team == "Maryland" & year(Date) >= 2025) |> 
  mutate(Season = year(Date)) |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(
    AvgPoints = mean(TeamScore),
    AvgOpponentPoints = mean(OpponentScore),
    AvgMargin = mean(TeamScore - OpponentScore),
    FG_PCT = mean(TeamFGPCT),
    ThreeP_PCT = mean(Team3PPCT),
    Turnovers = mean(TeamTurnovers)
  )




Code
buzz_summary <- buzz |> 
  group_by(Team, Season) |> 
  summarise(
  GamesPlayed = n(),
    Wins = sum(W_L == "W"),
    Losses = sum(W_L == "L"),
    AvgPoints = mean(TeamScore),
    AvgOpponentPoints = mean(OpponentScore),
    AvgMargin = mean(TeamScore - OpponentScore),
    FG_PCT = mean(TeamFGPCT),
    ThreeP_PCT = mean(Team3PPCT),
    FT_PCT = mean(TeamFTPCT),
    OffRebounds = mean(TeamOffRebounds),
    TotalRebounds = mean(TeamTotalRebounds),
    Assists = mean(TeamAssists),
    Steals = mean(TeamSteals),
    Blocks = mean(TeamBlocks),
    Turnovers = mean(TeamTurnovers),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )


Looking back at Buzz Williams’ teams at Virginia Tech and Texas A&M you can see they have a really clear identity. His teams are built on speed or flash as well as toughness, discipline, and consistency. Defensively, they slow opponents down keeping games in the 60s and low 70s, and force teams into difficult, contested shots without gambling for steals. At Texas A&M, his teams made a living on effort that they were some of the best offensive-rebounding teams in the country, constantly creating second chances and wearing opponents down over 40 minutes. Offensively, Williams shows that he likes structure and patience. His teams play deliberately, focusing on drawing a lot of fouls, and relying on efficient two-point scoring even during seasons when the three-point shooting wasn’t there. However, his teams can be turnover-prone, and their three-point shooting tends to come and go.
When you compare that to what Maryland has looked like the past couple seasons, they have already played slower than most of the Big Ten, defends at a high level, and has dealt with similar issues of scoring droughts, turnover problems, and inconsistent perimeter shooting.
